# Q - binwidth def

What does the `binwidth` argument specify?

## A

The width of the bins

## B

The range of x-axis values

## C

The number of bins

## D

The height of bars

## Answer

A

## Correct message

Correct!
As the name suggests, `binwidth` controls how wide each bin is.

The number of bins can be specified with the `bins` argument.
The height of bars is determined by the number of observations that fall into the corresponding bin.
The x-axis range is determined by the range of values in the data variable being plotted.

## Incorrect message

As the name suggests, `binwidth` controls how wide each bin is.

The number of bins can be specified with the `bins` argument.
The height of bars is determined by the number of observations that fall into the corresponding bin.
The x-axis range is determined by the range of values in the data variable being plotted.

# Q - bins def

What does the `bins` argument specify?

## A

The width of the bins

## B

The range of x-axis values

## C

The number of bins

## D

The height of bars

## Answer

C

## Correct message

Correct!
`bins` controls the number of bins to divide our data into.
For example, setting `bins = 20` will divide the data into 20 bins, and plot a bar for each bin.

The width of bins can be specified with the `binwidth` argument.
The height of bars is determined by the number of observations that fall into the corresponding bin.
The x-axis range is determined by the range of values in the data variable being plotted.

## Incorrect message

`bins` controls the number of bins to divide our data into.
For example, setting `bins = 20` will divide the data into 20 bins, and plot a bar for each bin.

The width of bins can be specified with the `binwidth` argument.
The height of bars is determined by the number of observations that fall into the corresponding bin.
The x-axis range is determined by the range of values in the data variable being plotted.

# Q - bins vs binwidth

Which statement is correct?

## A

Increasing `binwidth` of a histogram will reduce the total number of bins.

## B

Increasing `binwidth` of a histogram will increase the total number of bins.

## C

Increasing `binwidth` of a histogram has no effect on the number of bins plotted.

## Answer

A

## Correct message

Correct!
Larger bin width means that there will be fewer bins overall, and vice versa.
Try running the code in R to see how `binwidth` indirectly influences the number of bins.

```{r}
# No binwidth give: defaults to 30 bins
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white")

# Small binwidth of 0.1 results in more bins
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white",
                 binwidth = 0.1)
# Larger binwidth of 0.5 results in fewer bins
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white",
                 binwidth = 0.5)
```

If you specify both `bins` and `binwidth`, `bins` will be overridden by `binwidth`.

```{r}
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white",
                 binwidth = 0.25,
                 bins = 3) # this argument is ignored in favor of binwidth
```

## Incorrect message

Larger bin width means that there will be fewer bins overall, and vice versa.
Try running the code in R to see how `binwidth` indirectly influences the number of bins.

```{r}
# No binwidth give: defaults to 30 bins
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white")

# Small binwidth of 0.1 results in more bins
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white",
                 binwidth = 0.1)
# Larger binwidth of 0.5 results in fewer bins
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white",
                 binwidth = 0.5)
```

If you specify both `bins` and `binwidth`, `bins` will be overridden by `binwidth`.

```{r}
ggplot(data = iris,
       mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Length)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen",
                 color = "white",
                 binwidth = 0.25,
                 bins = 3) # this argument is ignored in favor of binwidth
```

# Q - KDE

You can plot a kernel density estimation curve with a histogram in {ggplot2} just by adding the function `geom_density()`.

## A

TRUE

## B

FALSE

## Answer

B

## Correct message

Simply adding the `geom_density()` function will give an error (see code below examples below).
You must also add a mapping to `geom_histogram()`, shown below.

```{r}
# Simple histogram
ggplot(data = mtcars, 
       mapping = aes(x = mpg)) + 
  geom_histogram()

# Error
ggplot(data = mtcars, 
       mapping = aes(x = mpg)) + 
  geom_histogram() +
  geom_density()

# Histogram overlaid with KDE
ggplot(data = mtcars, 
       mapping = aes(x = mpg)) + 
  geom_histogram(mapping = aes(y = after_stat(density))) +
  geom_density()
```

Refer to the lesson video or notes for more explanation!

## Incorrect message

Simply adding the `geom_density()` function will give an error (see code below examples below).
You must also add a mapping to `geom_histogram()`, shown below.

```{r}
# Simple histogram
ggplot(data = mtcars, 
       mapping = aes(x = mpg)) + 
  geom_histogram()

# Error
ggplot(data = mtcars, 
       mapping = aes(x = mpg)) + 
  geom_histogram() +
  geom_density()

# Histogram overlaid with KDE
ggplot(data = mtcars, 
       mapping = aes(x = mpg)) + 
  geom_histogram(mapping = aes(y = after_stat(density))) +
  geom_density()
```

Refer to the lesson video or notes for more explanation!

# Q - Boundary usage

What argument in `geom_histogram()` can you use to shift and align bins on a histogram?

## A

`bins` \## B `binwidth` \## C `boundary` \## D `breaks`

## Answer

C

## Correct message

Correct!
You can use the `boundary` argument in `geom_histogram()` to shift and align bins on a histogram.

## Incorrect message

You can use the `boundary` argument in `geom_histogram()` to shift and align bins on a histogram.

# Q - breaks usage

What argument in `geom_histogram()` can you use to set bin boundaries to a sequence of values?
## A `bins` \## B `binwidth` \## C `boundary` \## D `breaks`

# Answer

D

## Correct message

Correct!
You can use the `breaks` argument in `geom_histogram()` to set bin boundaries to a sequence of values.

The `boundary` argument is set to a single value, not a sequence, and it is used to shift and align bins on a histogram.

## Incorrect message

You can use the `breaks` argument in `geom_histogram()` to set bin boundaries to a sequence of values.

The `boundary` argument is set to a single value, not a sequence, and it is used to shift and align bins on a histogram.

# Q - precedence bins vs binwidth

What happens if you set the `binwidth` and `bins` arguments at the same time in `geom_histogram()`?

## A

R throws an error \## B `binwidth` takes precedence over `bins` \## C `bins` takes precedence over `binwidth` \## D Both arguments are ignored

## Answer

B

## Correct message

Right on!
If you set the `binwidth` and `bins` arguments at the same time in `geom_histogram()`, `binwidth` takes precedence over `bins`.

## Incorrect message

If you set the `binwidth` and `bins` arguments at the same time in `geom_histogram()`, `binwidth` takes precedence over `bins`.

# Q - boundary range (remove?)

What happens if you set the `boundary` argument to a value outside the range of the data in `geom_histogram()`?

## A

R throws an error \## B The histogram is still plotted with the closest boundary \## C The histogram is not plotted \## D The data is truncated at the boundary

## Answer

B

## Feedback message

If you set the `boundary` argument to a value outside the range of the data in `geom_histogram()`, the histogram is still plotted with the closest boundary.

# Q - default bins number

What is the default value for the `bins` argument in `geom_histogram()`?

## A

5 \## B 30 \## C 15 \## D 20

## Answer

B

## Correct message

Correct!
The default value for the `bins` argument in `geom_histogram()` is 30.

If you you don't modify the bins, you get a warning message that says "`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`."

## Incorrect message

The default value for the `bins` argument in `geom_histogram()` is 30.

If you you don't modify the bins, you get a warning message that says "`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth.`"

# Q - bounday with diamonds code example

```{r}
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = price)) +
  geom_histogram(boundary = 0, 
                 color = "white", 
                 fill = "dodgerblue",
                 binwidth = 500) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2500))

range(diamonds$price)
```
